intro: Ipomoea triloba f. lacunosa, commonly known as the lacunose morning glory, is a variant of the morning glory family (Convolvulaceae). It is characterized by its distinctive, lobed leaves and trumpet-shaped flowers that typically bloom in shades of purple or pink. The plant is native to the southeastern United States and thrives in moist, sunny environments. Its stems are twining and can climb, often forming a dense, sprawling growth. The leaves are palmately lobed, with a somewhat wavy or notched margin, contributing to its ornamental appeal.
